Pat Farrell wrote:

> But nearly all of my Java development is in a multi-threaded world.
> I'm surprized that you don't run into it. Nearly every thing I do
> is run as a servlet, so you have to be thread safe. And all of my
> systems have assorted daemons and background threads, which implement
> simple things like WorkingSetCaches or do long things like
> talking to radios that have to be dispatched asynchronously.

I run into it, but typically on platforms that do the dirty work for me, 
so I don't have to worry about it. That's what I meant. As for servlets, 
I don't typically store writable data in servlet fields, but rather only 
stateless services, so the multiple threads invoking a servlet don't 
bother me. This is a case where following a few simple rules eliminates 
the problem, rather than testing them out.

> And the AJAX folks are pushing the multi-threaded model even harder,
> with many more server clanks, and more chances for the server to get
> wrapped arround the axel with thread issues.

I have no idea how to test-drive Ajax stuff in Java. I've only done it 
in Ruby, and, once again, the multithreadedness doesn't much come up.

I merely favor eliminating the problem to solving it. I guess I've been 
working in domains that haven't forced me down the same roads you've 
been down.
